text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The candidate answer clearly explains that the Northern Ireland Protocol established that NI was effectively part of the EU single customs territory for goods (by aligning with EU rules and subjecting GB-NI trade to checks for goods 'at risk' of entering the EU single market), which aligns with the concept of NI functioning as a customs valve between the UK and EU markets. It contrasts this with the Windsor Framework, which modified this arrangement but retained the core principle of protecting the EU single market via checks on goods moving from GB to NI destined for the EU.", "criterion_id": "821ddcea-7e1d-45b8-8fba-32e37ae23575"}
